questions.text: A patient has underwent the canal wall down mastoidectomy for the treatment of cholesteatomas, which leads to the enlarged meatus now tell the name of Surgical procedure which involves reconstruction of cartilaginous part of external auditory canal?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meatoplasty Meatoplasty is the surgical procedure for the repair of meatus and cartilaginous part of external auditory canal during CWD surgery.

Highyeild:

Meatoplasty is an operation in which a crescent of conchal cartilage is excised to widen the meatus. It is invariably combined with all canal wall down procedures, i.e. modified radical and radical mastoidectomies for easy access to mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning. It is also done as an isolated procedure in a sagging auricle seen in older people. Sagging auricle obstructs the ear canal and causes hearing loss and retention of wax.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Canaloplasty is for the repair of bony part of external auditory canal OPTION B- Myringoplasty is the repair of myringus or tympanic membrane OPTION C- Tympanoplasty is the surgical operation performed for the reconstruction of the ear drum or the small bones of middle ear (ossicles)

questions.text: A patient of 25yr/M came to the Aiims OPD presented with fever and difficulty in swallowing on oral examination following observations are seen as in below image Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peritonsillar abscess Above image shows quinsy/peritonsillar abscess.

Highyeild:

QUINSY/PERITONSILLAR ABSCESS It is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. Clinical features sore throat drooling of saliva trismus fever Management- antibiotics and incision and drainage followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 20 yr/f was moving towards her home by two wheels suddenly she fell down and had a fracture in middle cranial fossa. Identify the sign shown in given image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Battle sign Image shown is of Battle sign.

Highyeild:

Battle Sign (also called Battle's Sign) is defined as bruising over the mastoid process. It is retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that is typically the result of head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of petrous temporal bone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Bryce sign seen during laryngocele and Zenker’s diverticulum OPTION C- Water sign is not seen anywhere. OPTION D- Griesinger sign seen in lateral sinus thrombophlebitis

questions.text: Tubercular otitis media is characterized by all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Painful otorrhea Ear ache/ painful otorrhea is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

Highyeild:

Tubercular otitis media is characterized by following features Painless otorrhea Multiple perforations Foul smelling watery ear discharge Pale granulations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Multiple perforations, two or three in number, are seen in pars tensa and form a classical sign of disease. OPTION C- Pale granulations is also a feature of tubercular otitis media. OPTION D- Foul smelling watery ear discharge is also a feature of tubercular otitis media.

questions.text: A child was brought to doctor along with x-ray with the complain of barking cough, fever, Hoarse voice noisy or labored breathing typically worse at night. The given X – Ray of the patient shows Steeple sign, therefore the probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis Steeple sign/ Pencil tip sign in radiology, the steeple sign is a radiologic sign found on a frontal neck radiograph where subglottic tracheal narrowing produces the shape of a church steeple within the trachea itself. The presence of the steeple sign supports a diagnosis of croup or acute laryngotracheobronchitis usually caused by paramyxoviruses.

Highyeild:

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup is a viral infection caused by parainfluenzae type 1, 2, and sometimes 3. Critical area involved is subglottic larynx producing oedema with stridor and respiratory distress. X-ray (PA view) larynx shows typical “steeple sign” but X-rays are avoided as any manipulation may precipitate acute obstruction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- In acute epiglottitis thumb sign is seen on x ray. OPTION C- In laryngomalacia omega shaped epiglottis is seen. OPTION D - Laryngeal web is due to incomplete recanalization of larynx. Mostly, the web is seen between the vocal cords and has a concave posterior margin. Presenting features are airway obstruction, weak cry or aphonia dating from birth.

questions.text: Occipito-mental view with open mouth view to check for nose and paranasal sinuses?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pierre View The correct answer is the Pierre View when using the Occipito-Mental (OM) projection with an open mouth to visualize the nose and paranasal sinuses. The other views mentioned (Water's view, Caldwell view, and Towne's view) are used for different purposes, such as visualizing maxillary sinuses, frontal sinuses, and the skull base, respectively.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options: Option A: Water's View: This is not the correct answer. The Water's view is an X-ray technique used to visualize the maxillary sinuses. The patient is positioned with the head tilted forward over the edge of the examination table. The X-ray beam is directed through the open mouth, which allows for a frontal view of the maxillary sinuses. Option B: Caldwell View: This is not the correct answer either. The Caldwell view is a radiographic projection used to visualize the frontal sinuses and orbital rims. In this view, the patient's head is tilted backward, and the X-ray beam is directed through the forehead, producing an image of the frontal sinuses. Option C: Towne's View: This is not the correct answer. The Towne's view, also known as the Posteroanterior (PA) axial view, is primarily used for imaging the skull base, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum. It involves angling the X-ray beam from a posterior-to-anterior direction, creating an image that highlights the base of the skull.

questions.text: A patient came to ENT clinic with the symptoms of crusting in nasal cavity, nasal obstruction, nose bleeds and patient also told the doctor that his wife sleeps away from him because of strong, fowl, smell comes from his breath now doctor advise him for Partial closure of nasal orifice done in which condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atrophic rhinitis From the above history it is clear that patient is having Atrophic rhinitis . Complete /partial closure of nostrils is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

Highyeild:

Atrophic Rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The nasal cavities are roomy and full of foul-smelling crusts. Atrophic rhinitis – 2 kinds of operations present for this condition Young operation – in this complete closure of nasal orifice, if only one nasal cavity is affected Modified young options – in this partial closure of nasal orifice, if both the nasal cavity is affected .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- In Chronic fungal aspergillosis Fess (Functional Endoscopic sinus surgery) is done. OPTION C- In Vasomotor rhinitis Viridian neurectomy is done. OPTION D- In Fungal mucormycosis Debridement of tissue with FESS is done.

questions.text: Stimulation of external auditory canal leads to cough due to which nerve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Auricular branch Vagus Cough on scratching the external auditory canal is due to the auricular branch of vagus nerve also called as arnold nerve.

Highyeild:

Five nerves supply the ear out of which three are cranial nerve that is Auriculotemporal, Arnold (tenth), Auricular branch of facial nerve and two from cervical plexus that is Greater auricular and lesser occipital Vagus nerve also supply larynx in the form of superior and recurrent laryngeal nerve Stimulation of vagus produces cough as it also supplies larynx

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B, C ,D - All these nerves are not involved in cough reflex due to stimulation of external auditory canal.

questions.text: A 45yr/f has diagnosed with benign neoplasms and doctor has advise her to remove that mass for which she underwent a parotid surgery. Not a surgical landmark for parotid surgery?

options.label: D
options.text: Facial nerve dissecting from peripheral branches

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inferior belly of omohyoid Following are the Parotid landmarks Tragal pointer, Posterior belly of digastric, branches of facial nerve dissecting from peripheral branches

questions.text: Inner ear of human consists of three parts cochlea, vestibule and semicircular canal. Saccule develop from which part?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pars inferior Saccule develops from pars inferior.

Highyeild:

Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicle or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea). The embryologic source and the time of development of external and middle ears are quite independent of the development of the inner ear. It is therefore not unusual to see malformed and nonfunctional inner ear in the presence of normal external and middle ears, and vice versa.

Extraedge:

Name of part Development Cochlea Pars inferior Saccule(part of vestibule) Pars inferior Utricle(part of vestibule) Pars Superior Semicircular canal Pars Superior
